channel.title: NYT > Well
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: The 5 Unofficial Love Languages
item.description: For Valentine’s Day, relationship experts share a few ways to show our partners that we care.
item.dc:creator: Jancee Dunn

item.title: James Van Der Beek’s Death Underscores Early-Onset Colorectal Cancers
item.description: The actor James Van Der Beek, who died on Wednesday at 48, was among a growing number of adults under 50 diagnosed with the disease.
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal

item.title: What Does Grief Look Like?
item.description: A death doula reflects on the many ways people process loss — even when tears don’t come.
item.dc:creator: Darnell Lamont Walker

item.title: Alcohol’s Effects on the Body: What Does Drinking Do to Your Health?
item.description: From the moment you take a sip, drinking starts to influence your biology. Here’s an inside look.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith and Montse Galbany

item.title: My Sister Has Been Cruel to Me Since Her Husband Died
item.description: Our Ask the Therapist columnist, Lori Gottlieb, advises a reader who is feuding with a sister after the death of her spouse.
item.dc:creator: Lori Gottlieb

item.title: Are Antidepressants Safe During Pregnancy?
item.description: Confusion about the safety of taking the drugs during pregnancy has led to mental health emergencies for some expectant mothers, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Claire Merchlinsky/The New York Times; Photographs by Getty

item.title: Winter Olympics: How Athletes Handle Disappointment (and How You Can Too)
item.description: Dealing with failure is part of the job for elite athletes. Here’s how they cope with it.
item.dc:creator: Gloria Liu
item.media:description: The snowboarder Lindsey Jacobellis hugs her teammate at the 2022 Olympics, 16 years after she crashed in the final stretch of the race at her first Games in Torino.

item.title: Peter Attia’s Ties to Epstein Spark a Backlash From Doctors
item.description: What started as a rebuke of Dr. Attia has become a discussion about his credentials, longevity medicine and whom patients should trust.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: Measles Outbreak Hits Ave Maria University in Florida
item.description: More than 40 people have fallen ill at Ave Maria University, raising fears that college campuses may soon experience more measles outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times

item.title: New Method Can Find Hidden Eggs to Aid in Fertility Treatment
item.description: A study reported that the conventional method of searching follicular fluid didn’t find all the eggs. The new technology found extra eggs more than half the time.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A viable egg found by the OvaReady device that was not found using the conventional method.

item.title: TV, It’s Not Just for Humans Anymore
item.description: Videos aimed at pets are drawing millions of views. But who’s actually watching?
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Four States Sue Administration Over Loss of Public Health Funds
item.description: The states, all led by Democrats, claim the cuts were intended as retribution and will harm efforts to control H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted infections.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. The agency administered block grants for H.I.V. prevention that were allocated to public health departments in California, Colorado, Illinois and Minnesota.

item.title: U.S. Health Officials Defend Rejection of Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.description: The F.D.A.’s refusal to examine the company’s mRNA shot drew widespread criticism from doctors and was divisive within the agency.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Marty Makary, the F.D.A. commissioner, suggested that the agency might eventually approve Moderna’s mRNA flu vaccine.

item.title: The Secret to Happiness May Lie in Our Social Skills
item.description: A new book, “How to Feel Loved,” links our social skills to how content we are.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: How to Feel Loved: The Five Mindsets That Get You More of What Matters Most (Book)

item.title: Dr. Oz Says Drinking Is a ‘Social Lubricant.’ Some Experts Worry About That.
item.description: “Most of the harm that comes from alcohol,” said one researcher, is “due mostly or mainly to drinking with their buddies.”
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Edu Bayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most research examining the effects of alcohol in a controlled laboratory setting has ignored the social context in which most drinking occurs.

item.title: Baking for Your Valentine? This Psychologist Would Like a Word.
item.description: Helen Goh, the British baker and therapist, thinks romantic treats can be tricky. She advises tailoring them to the length of your relationship.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times

item.title: Are Garlic Supplements Good for Your Heart?
item.description: Some claim to support healthy blood pressure and cholesterol levels. We asked experts if that’s true.
item.dc:creator: Marlene Cimons
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Administration to Cut $600 Million in Health Funding From Four States
item.description: The states, all led by Democrats, used the grants to support a wide variety of functions, including H.I.V. prevention and surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Cuts totaling about $600 million will affect funds to health departments and smaller partner organizations, including the Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago.

item.title: What to Know About Measles as Cases Rise: Symptoms, Vaccine and More
item.description: Here’s why we’re seeing so many cases now, and what to know about the risks of infection.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Teddy Rosenbluth

item.title: Oz Offers Forceful Call for Measles Vaccination
item.description: The comments by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services director come as South Carolina grapples with a large measles outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

item.title: How Are Health Care Costs Affecting You?
item.description: We want to hear from readers who are trying to manage their medical bills and their health insurance costs.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson

item.title: A.I. Is Making Doctors Answer a Question: What Are They Really Good For?
item.description: Many physicians find chatbots threatening, but that doesn’t mean they’re giving up on medicine.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: Health Advice From A.I. Chatbots Is Frequently Wrong, Study Shows
item.description: In part, the problem has to do with how users are asking their questions.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times

item.title: Do You Really Need Collagen and Other Popular Supplements? Here’s What Doctors Suggest.
item.description: Magnesium, fiber, protein powder, collagen — here’s what doctors actually recommend.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan and Ghazalle Badiozamani for The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ghazalle Badiozamani for The New York Times

item.title: 2 to 3 Cups of Coffee a Day May Reduce Dementia Risk. But Not if It’s Decaf.
item.description: One to two cups of caffeinated tea per day helps too, researchers found after following nearly 132,000 people for 40 years.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.media:description: Beyond two and a half cups of coffee daily, the advantage plateaued, possibly because there’s a limit to how much caffeine our bodies can metabolize, researchers said.

item.title: How Artists Beat the Blues
item.description: Ten creative people share their strategies for thriving, or at least getting by, in difficult times.
item.dc:creator: Kimberly Bradley

item.title: How Healthy Are Mushrooms?
item.description: Their rich, meaty flavor isn’t the only reason to eat them regularly.
item.dc:creator: Simar Bajaj

item.title: 4 Dead in Mushroom Poisoning Outbreak in California
item.description: State health officials discouraged foraging this year, saying that toxic mushrooms can easily be confused with safe ones to eat.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: California Department of Public Health, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Complications from death cap mushroom poisoning can include liver and kidney failure and seizures.

item.title: 5 Conversations to Have With Your Aging Parents
item.description: Many families put these talks off. But having them now can lead to better care later.
item.dc:creator: Simar Bajaj
